user_message:
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used. You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations. Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines. They will investigate the code fragments you give. Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule. Provide your answer with these fields. - suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code. It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags - explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated. It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated. DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments. Here is the code of init_response_body_data: ```c static int init_response_body_data (void) { if (0 != body_dyn_size) { body_dyn = (char *) malloc (body_dyn_size); if (NULL == body_dyn) { fprintf (stderr, "Failed to allocate memory.\n"); return 0; } if (tool_params.medium) { /* Fill the body with HTML-like content */ size_t pos; size_t filler_pos; static const char body_header[] = "\n" "\nSample page title\n\n" "\n"; static const char body_filler[] = "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
\n"; static const char body_footer[] = "\n" "\n"; pos = 0; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_header, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header)); pos += MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header); for (filler_pos = 0; filler_pos < (body_dyn_size - (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header) + MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer))); ++filler_pos) { body_dyn[pos + filler_pos] = body_filler[filler_pos % MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_filler)]; } pos += filler_pos; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_footer, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer)); } else { /* Fill the body with binary-like content */ size_t pos; for (pos = 0; pos < body_dyn_size; ++pos) { body_dyn[pos] = (char) (unsigned char) (255U - pos % 256U); } } } return ! 0; } ``` Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of compiler language extensions in the provided function. The code only uses standard ISO C constructs: static storage, function prototype with (void), standard types (size_t, char), string literals (standard concatenation), standard library functions (malloc, memcpy, fprintf), casts, arithmetic and control flow (for, if), and a macro MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (a macro itself is not a language extension). There are no compiler-specific keywords or notations such as __attribute__, __asm/asm, __builtin_*, typeof, __declspec, #pragma with vendor-specific pragmas, extended integer types, or other documented compiler extensions. The odd-looking "return ! 0;" is valid standard C (evaluates to 0) and is not a compiler extension. Therefore there are no fragments to report for Rule 1.2.
